Package edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.logic

Interface Expression

All Superinterfaces:
Comparable<Logical>, Logical, Serializable, Simplifiable, Typed
All Known Subinterfaces:
Atom, Numeric, Parameter, Proposition, Value
All Known Implementing Classes:
Arithmetic, ArithmeticExpansion, Assignment, Character, Clause, Comparison, CompiledFluent, Conditional, Conjunction, Disjunction, Effect, Entity, Epistemic, False, Fluent, Negation, Number, Precondition, PrefixFluent, Quantified, True, TypeConstraint, Unknown, Variable
public interface Expression extends Typed, Simplifiable
A logical expression is a logical formula which can be evaluated in a state to return a value.
Author:
Stephen G. Ware

  • Method Details

    • apply

      Expression apply(Function<Object,Object> function)
      Description copied from interface: Logical
      Applies a given function to every part of this logical formula and then creates a new logical formula of this same type using the results returned from the function. If, for every part of this formula, the function always returns its input as output with no changes, this method should return this object (not just any object that is equal to this object).
      Specified by:
      apply in interface Logical
      Specified by:
      apply in interface Simplifiable
      Parameters:
      function - the function to apply to all parts of this formula
      Returns:
      a logical formula of the same type as this formula made from the returned objects, or this object if no parts were changed by the function

    • simplify

      default Expression simplify()
      Description copied from interface: Simplifiable
      Returns a logically equivalent but smaller, simpler, or more convenient form of this logical formula.
      Specified by:
      simplify in interface Simplifiable
      Returns:
      a smaller, simpler, or more convenient logical formula which is equivalent to this formula

    • isValued

      default boolean isValued()
      Tests whether or not this expression is a valued expression. A valued expression is a value or an expression which describes a value and cannot be simplified any further without knowing the current state. Valued expressions are the only kind of expression which can appear on the right side of an effect's assignment. Valued expressions include:
      • a value
      • a variable
      • a numeric fluent
      • an arithmetic expression composed only of other valued expressions
      This method returns false by default and should be overridden by expressions which are or can be valued expressions.
      Returns:
      true if the expression describes a value and cannot be further simplified without knowing the current state, false otherwise

    • mustBeValued

      default void mustBeValued()
      If this expression is valued, this method does nothing; if it is not valued, an exception is thrown.
      Throws:
      FormatException - if the expression is not valued

    • evaluate

      Value evaluate(State state)
      Returns the value of this expression in a given state.
      Parameters:
      state - the state in which this expression will be evaluated
      Returns:
      the value of this expression

    • prepend

      default Expression prepend(Parameter character)
      Returns an expression which represents a character's beliefs about this expression.
      Parameters:
      character - the character whose beliefs will be represented
      Returns:
      an expression representing the character's beliefs about this expression

    • negate

      default Expression negate()
      If this expression is of type boolean, this method returns an expression that will always have the opposite value; if this expression is of any other type, or cannot be negated, this method thrown an exception.
      Returns:
      an expression with the opposite value of this expression
      Throws:
      FormatException - if this expression cannot be negated, usually because it is not of type boolean

    • toValued

      default Conditional<Disjunction<Clause<Precondition>>> toValued()
      Returns a conditional expression whose conditions are in disjunctive normal form and whose branches are valued expressions. This method is used to simplify expressions by converting anything which is not valued into valued expressions and moving any conditionals outside of the expression. If the expression is already valued, the conditional returned should have no conditions and a single branch that is this expression.
      Returns:
      a conditional with conditions in disjunctive normal form and branches that are valued expressions

    • toPrecondition

      default Disjunction<Clause<Precondition>> toPrecondition()
      Converts an expression whose type is boolean to disjunctive normal form (DNF) suitable to appear in the precondition of an event. A DNF expression is a disjunction of conjunctive clauses whose atoms are preconditions.
      Returns:
      a disjunction of conjunctive clauses whose atoms are preconditions
      Throws:
      FormatException - if the expression is not boolean or cannot be converted to DNF

    • toEffect

      default Clause<Effect> toEffect()
      Converts an expression whose type is boolean to disjunctive normal form (DNF) suitable to appear in the deterministic effect of an event. Because effects must be deterministic, this process must result in a disjunction of no more than one conjunctive clause whose atoms are effects. Because there will only be at most one clause, that clause is returned instead of a disjunction. If no clauses would be returned (in other words, if false would be returned), the null clause is returned.
      Returns:
      a conjunctive clause whose atoms are effects
      Throws:
      FormatException - if the expression is not boolean, is not deterministic, or cannot be converted to DNF
